course_title: Multivariate Data Analysis & Machine Learning in Biology

learning_outcomes.description: Manipulate, visualise and analyse realistic, large ecological datasets
Understand the applications of supervised and unsupervised learning and how to implement them
Communicate complex analyses to a general audience
Identify appropriate analytical techniques for diverse biological problems
Use R to perform analyses on complex multivariate datasets
Understand multivariate data structures and summary statistics

assessments.assessment_title: Engagement with Pre-class Reading (Supervised Learning Module)
assessments.task_description:
This assessment requires students to submit three questions related to the pre-class reading for each of weeks 2-5 (2.5% each) of the supervised learning module.

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Online submission by Turnitin only by the due date. No hard copy or assignment cover sheets required.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Students will submit a comprehensively documented R notebook detailing all the steps (data import and cleaning through to presentation and discussion of results) of an analysis on a dataset they have not seen before.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Online submission by Turnitin only by the due date. No hard copy or assignment cover sheets required.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Engagement with Pre-class Reading (Unsupervised Learning Module)
assessments.task_description:
This assessment requires students to submit three questions related to the pre-class reading for 4 out of the 5 weeks (2.5% each week) of the unsupervised learning module.

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Written report (1,000 words), critical interpretation of an existing analysis / results section.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

learning_activities.topic:
Foundations in supervised learning

Foundation concepts including: bias-variance trade-off, over-fitting, cross-validation, precision and recall, classification and regression (Letten)
learning_activities.topic_description: Foundations in supervised learning Foundation concepts including: bias-variance trade-off, over-fitting, cross-validation, precision and recall, classification and regression (Letten)

learning_activities.topic:
All the algorithms

Introduction to different supervised learning algorithms: k-nearest neighbours, naive Bayes, support vector machines, decision/regression trees and random forests, and neural networks (Letten)
learning_activities.topic_description: All the algorithms Introduction to different supervised learning algorithms: k-nearest neighbours, naive Bayes, support vector machines, decision/regression trees and random forests, and neural networks (Letten)

learning_activities.topic:
Decision and regression trees

Decision and regression tree basics and ensemble learning (Letten)
learning_activities.topic_description: Decision and regression trees Decision and regression tree basics and ensemble learning (Letten)
Deep learning with neural networks I (Letten)
Deep learning with neural networks II (Letten)
